in March the Head of the State
Internet Information Office

2569.14.text:
actually brought in all of these
bunch of big V's, and actually

2574.10.text:
He called them in, sat
them down, and said,

2576.21.text:
look, we need to make sure
that social media in the future

2579.38.text:
isn't filled with rumors, isn't
filled with malicious lies.

2581.88.text:
We have to make sure
that what we're posting

2583.71.text:
is supportive of the
health of society.

2591.25.text:
And over the summer actually,
there was a big crack down,

2594.34.text:
and a lot of these big V's
were actually dragged in.

2596.51.text:
There was one economic
writer, Charles Xue,

2602.19.text:
He had to do this
forced confession.

2604.79.text:
There are other folks who
have been arrested recently.

2607.04.text:
So it's clear that
the government

2609.17.text:
is very interested in
targeting individuals, as well,

2619.82.text:
has its own version
of Twitter and things

2623.05.text:
that Youku for YouTube
and Baidu for Google.

2626.47.text:
How much urgency do you
sense from Chinese users

2629.81.text:
to use the Western generated
products versus use their own,

2634.99.text:
and have more
censorship on them.

2637.30.text:
Because I don't
sense a lot of need

2639.55.text:
to use Google over Baidu but it
obviously [INAUDIBLE] search.

2648.36.text:
Obviously, there are
hardcore folks within China

2651.05.text:
who are very adamant about using
products that aren't censored.

2654.65.text:
So when Google did
pull out of China,

2656.37.text:
you had people laying wreaths
and flowers at the Google

2658.66.text:
Office, because they were
really saddened by the fact

2661.77.text:
that a company like
Google left China,

2665.21.text:
and now they were
forced to use products

2667.08.text:
like Baidu-- which if
you haven't used Baidu,

2669.51.text:
it's actually a pretty
good search tool

2671.57.text:
so long as you're not searching
for sensitive content.

2674.91.text:
So I think there are folks who
are very, very much into using

2683.59.text:
Twitter and YouTube
from within China.

2685.18.text:
And the thing is,
for the most part,

2687.04.text:
if you want to use Twitter
and Facebook within China,

2690.40.text:
you have the tools to allow
you to get access to them.

2692.97.text:
It's not like Iran
where sometimes they

2694.78.text:
throttle the
internet to the point

2698.32.text:
You could actually
use-- well, now VPN's

2701.31.text:
a little more dicey
since it's harder to get.

2703.34.text:
It's a good, solid VPN
that works for a while.

2705.26.text:
But you can use various
types of circumvention tools

2708.45.text:
to get access to YouTube,
Facebook, Twitter

2710.65.text:
from within China
if you want to.

2712.99.text:
The thing is, most
folks-- why go

2714.98.text:
on Twitter when all your
friends are on Weibo?

2716.90.text:
It's network effect, so
it's fairly entrenched

2720.24.text:
at this point, Weibo and
other sorts of social media.

2724.62.text:
So I think for the most
part, Chinese internet users,

2727.92.text:
some of them may actually
use domestic products out

2731.95.text:
For the most, I think folks are
just-- not necessarily lazy,

2739.88.text:
but that's the
thing that loads up

2742.00.text:
when they can start their
computer, that's what they use.

2746.34.text:
AUDIENCE: Just to follow
up about on the question

2750.35.text:
The way for the content
creators side [INAUDIBLE],

2759.47.text:
is there any sense,
especially given

2761.41.text:
that it's not just
the China-- you

2769.50.text:
Is there any sense or
precedent that China

2772.52.text:
might be saving query
traffic across all users

2777.00.text:
to find who searched
for certain [INAUDIBLE]

2789.33.text:
So the question was--
again, going back

2791.28.text:
to whether the government
is tracking people

2796.40.text:
with regards, especially
to sucking up metadata,

2799.04.text:
and whether or not
we think companies

2801.99.text:
like Sina or the government
are using this sort of metadata

2805.93.text:
as a way to figure out
who should be brought in

2811.50.text:
So I certainly
don't have knowledge

2816.72.text:
of metadata being used
in this sort of fashion.

2821.08.text:
I think from the sort
of anecdotal evidence

2824.88.text:
that we have, it's more
straight surveillance.

2828.64.text:
If they know that
your a activist,

2832.84.text:
they may get access to
your WeChat account,

2836.22.text:
and then start tracking
the messages you post.

2838.57.text:
And then when you
say, oh, I'm going

2840.08.text:
to be having lunch at
the Chaoyang Square

2842.50.text:
or whatever, they send an
officer who follows you.

2846.83.text:
And then you get
there, and you notice

2848.41.text:
how the officer is there, and
you wonder how they got there.

2850.91.text:
So that's the sort of thing
that I think their method

2859.71.text:
As for figuring out-- from
the vast, big data who

2866.46.text:
I'm sure that their
equivalent of the NSA

2868.68.text:
is doing the same sort of thing
that the NSA is doing here.

2872.61.text:
But I don't know if individual
netizens who are just,

2878.38.text:
should be worried that
they're metadata's

2880.78.text:
going to be sucked up,
and then somehow they're

2882.74.text: going to end up in prison.

2889.80.text:
They know who they
should be focused on,

2891.82.text:
and I think that's not
their primary target.

2897.97.text:
AUDIENCE: A question just
referring to China's NSA,

2901.51.text:
and we haven't really
talked much about

2907.40.text:
I wonder if they're
just concentrated solely

2911.68.text:
in the Propaganda Ministry
that has controls on this?

2915.21.text:
Or are there multiple
agencies or groups

2919.03.text:
that are involved censorship
in China, from what

2921.28.text:
you can infer from
your research?

2924.28.text:
So the question was
about who's actually

2925.63.text:
performing the sort of
censorship, what government

2933.17.text:
that's politically
driven in some ways.

2935.23.text:
So you have this new bureau
called the State Internet

2942.16.text:
of an offshoot of the State
Council Information Office,

2945.24.text:
which is now supposedly the
lead figure for performing

2951.36.text:
But you have all
these other ministries

2955.67.text:
But you also have not just
these multiple agencies

2958.26.text:
and bureaucracies, but you
also to notice that there's

2960.60.text:
a national level of
information control,

2962.70.text:
but then you also have local
officials who are involved.

2966.79.text:
and other folks who have
different interests than maybe

2972.89.text:
So you have these
different layers.

2975.33.text:
And then you throw
into that, you

2976.70.text:
have private companies who have
a vested interest in preventing

2982.22.text:
any sort of potentially even
sensitive discussion taking

2986.10.text:
So you have another layer
of censorship there,

2988.14.text:
and then you have the
actual users themselves

2990.02.text:
who have to self-censor,
who actually report

2993.73.text:
on other users who are
posting provocative content.

2995.91.text:
So you have these
multiple layers,

3000.95.text:
It's not as simple as they're
doing it, or it's them.

3005.11.text:
It's very much a de-centralized,
diffused censorship system,

3008.54.text:
which is, I think, a feature
of the Chinese system.

3015.51.text:
All right, I think
everyone is too scared,

3019.46.text:
and we're going
to call it quits.

3020.88.text:
All right, thanks so
much everyone for--
